messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Maximum Clique in Disk-Like Intersection Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the complexity of Maximum Clique in intersection graphs of convex objects in the plane. On the algorithmic side, we extend the polynomial-time algorithm for unit disks [Clark ‚Äô90, Raghavan and Spinrad ‚Äô03] to translates of any fixed convex set. We also generalize the efficient polynomial-time approximation scheme (EPTAS) and subexponential algorithm for disks [Bonnet et al. ‚Äô18, Bonamy et al. ‚Äô18] to homothets of a fixed centrally symmetric convex set. The main open question on that topic is the complexity of Maximum Clique in disk graphs. It is not known whether this problem is NP-hard. We observe that, so far, all the hardness proofs for Maximum Clique in intersection graph classes ‚Ñê‚Ñê\mathcal{I} follow the same road. They show that, for every graph Gùê∫G of a large-enough class ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, the complement of an even subdivision of Gùê∫G belongs to the intersection class ‚Ñê‚Ñê\mathcal{I}. Then they conclude invoking the hardness of Maximum Independent Set on the class ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, and the fact that the even subdivision preserves that hardness. However there is a strong evidence that this approach cannot work for disk graphs [Bonnet et al. ‚Äô18]. We suggest a new approach, based on a problem that we dub Max Interval Permutation Avoidance, which we prove unlikely to have a subexponential-time approximation scheme. We transfer that hardness to Maximum Clique in intersection graphs of objects which can be either half-planes (or unit disks) or axis-parallel rectangles. That problem is not amenable to the previous approach. We hope that a scaled down (merely NP-hard) variant of Max Interval Permutation Avoidance could help making progress on the disk case, for instance by showing the NP-hardness for (convex) pseudo-disks.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Classifying convex bodies by their contact and intersection graphs",
        "Connecting the dots (with minimum crossings)",
        "Some APX-completeness results for cubic graphs",
        "The probabilistic method",
        "On pseudo-disk hypergraphs",
        "Efficient amplifiers and bounded degree optimization",
        "EPTAS for max clique on disks and unit balls",
        "On Subexponential and FPT-Time Inapproximability",
        "QPTAS and subexponential algorithm for maximum clique on disk graphs",
        "Parameterized hardness of art gallery problems",
        "Optimality program in segment and string graphs",
        "Graph classes: a survey",
        "Unit disk graph recognition is NP-hard",
        "Homothetic polygons and beyond: Maximal cliques in intersection graphs",
        "Optimization problems in multiple-interval graphs",
        "The clique problem in ray intersection graphs",
        "Stabbing pairwise intersecting disks by four points",
        "Every planar graph is the intersection graph of segments in the plane: extended abstract",
        "Polynomial-time approximation schemes for packing and piercing fat objects",
        "Unit disk graphs",
        "Zur l√∂sung des gallaischen problems √ºber kreisscheiben in der euklidischen ebene",
        "Graph Theory, 4th Edition, volume 173 of Graduate texts in mathematics",
        "Difference equations, isoperimetric inequality and transience of certain random walks",
        "Finding the maximal cut in a graph",
        "Polynomial-time approximation schemes for geometric intersection graphs",
        "Disk graphs: A short survey",
        "The Maximum Clique Problem in Multiple Interval Graphs",
        "Explicit constructions of linear-sized superconcentrators",
        "Complexity of finding perfect bipartite matchings minimizing the number of intersecting edges",
        "Stabbing pairwise intersecting disks by five points",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "3-SAT faster and simpler - unique-SAT bounds for PPSZ hold in general",
        "Representing graphs by disks and balls (a survey of recognition-complexity results)",
        "Expander graphs and their applications",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Sphere and Dot Product Representations of Graphs",
        "On the chromatic number of intersection graphs of convex sets in the plane",
        "Kontaktprobleme der konformen Abbildung",
        "String graphs. II. recognizing string graphs is NP-hard",
        "Intersection graphs of segments",
        "Parameterized complexity of independence and domination on geometric graphs",
        "Optimal parameterized algorithms for planar facility location problems using voronoi diagrams",
        "Topics in intersection graph theory",
        "The max clique problem in classes of string-graphs",
        "Planar NAE3SAT is in P",
        "Sub-constant error probabilistically checkable proof of almost-linear size",
        "A PTAS for the minimum dominating set problem in unit disk graphs",
        "A robust PTAS for maximum weight independent sets in unit disk graphs",
        "An improved exponential-time algorithm for k-SAT",
        "A note on stable sets and colorings of graphs",
        "Robust algorithms for restricted domains",
        "Recognizing string graphs in NP",
        "A solution of gallai‚Äôs problem on pinning down circles",
        "Better approximation schemes for disk graphs",
        "Optimization and Approximation on Systems of Geometric Objects"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Maximum Clique in Disk-Like Intersection Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
